html:
Synopsis

Money managers and analysts are betting on investors shifting money out of industrials to consumer-oriented stocks in consumer goods, consumer discretionary and automobile sectors in the foreseeable future,

Mumbai: Manufacturing, infrastructure, and capital goods - the investment themes that dominated India's equity landscape in the past three years - may lose favour with investors as consumption is poised to take centre stage after the income tax cuts in the budget last week.

Money managers and analysts are betting on investors shifting money out of industrials to consumer-oriented stocks in consumer goods, consumer discretionary and automobile sectors in the foreseeable future,

"The lowering of income tax has made consumption stocks even better bets and they will benefit at the cost of industrials and capex-related space," said Siddarth Bhamre, head-institutional research at Asit C Mehta Investments. "The shift in money from industrials to consumption had already started and now after this tax cut, it will only accelerate."

In response to the budget on Saturday, the BSE Capital Goods Index tumbled 3% while the Infrastructure and Industrials indices fell over 2.5% each. The Manufacturing index ended marginally lower. Meanwhile, the BSE Consumer Durables, Consumer Discretionary and Fast Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) indices surged around 2.5% each.

By cutting income taxes, the government wants to put more money into the hands of individuals and encourage them to spend, a move aimed at reviving flagging consumption.

Motilal Oswal Financial Services said the budget, for the first time in many years, chose to stimulate consumption and savings instead of focusing on capex.

Bhamre is most bullish on paints, consumer durables such as electric goods manufacturers, and two-wheeler maker Bajaj Auto because most of these stocks have been underperformers and will benefit from an increase in consumption.

"Consumption stocks are expected to lead the market rally in the near to medium term," said Divam Sharma, Founder and Fund manager, Green Portfolio PMS. "The increased spending by the middle class could also alleviate the lower growth numbers in auto and FMCG companies."

Though the tide on Dalal Street is against manufacturing and industrials in the near future, market participants warned against writing the theme off.
